questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for varicose veins. Following the procedure, he developed sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve, provides cutaneous sensation to the medial side of the leg and foot.

  • It is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.
  • The nerve courses along the great saphenous vein in the medial leg.
  • During varicose vein surgery, particularly when the great saphenous vein is handled, the saphenous nerve is vulnerable to injury due to its close anatomical relationship.


Explanation of incorrect options:

Sural nerve (Option A): Provides cutaneous sensation over the lateral foot and dorsum near the little toe, not the medial leg and foot.

Superficial peroneal nerve (Option B): Supplies the anterolateral leg and most of the dorsum of the foot, sparing the medial leg and first web space.

Deep peroneal nerve (Option C): Responsible for sensory innervation of only the first dorsal web space between the hallux and the second toe, not the medial leg.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a fever and massive splenomegaly. The spleen was 15 cm on palpation and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold extending from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm.

  • It acts as a shelf supporting the spleen from below.
  • By this positioning, it prevents vertical and downward displacement of the spleen into the left lower quadrant.
  • This anatomical support becomes especially relevant in massive splenomegaly, where the spleen enlarges but is restricted from descending further by this ligament.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Lienorenal ligament (Option A):

  • Also called the splenorenal ligament.
  • Connects the spleen to the left kidney.
  • Contains the splenic vessels and tail of the pancreas.
  • Provides posterior support to the spleen but does not prevent its downward descent.

Gastrosplenic ligament (Option B):

  • Connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.
  • Contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery.
  • Provides anteromedial stabilization, but does not limit vertical descent.

Lienophrenic ligament (Option D):

  • Also known as the splenophrenic ligament.
  • Connects the spleen to the diaphragm superiorly.
  • Provides upward support, thus preventing upward displacement of the spleen, not downward movement.

Reference:

  1. [The ligament system of the spleen and its significance for surgical interventions] - PubMed
  2. Splenic Anomalies of Shape, Size, and Location: Pictorial Essay - PMC

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lingual nerve passes in very close proximity to the submandibular gland and its duct, making it particularly vulnerable to injury during gland resection.

Functions affected if the lingual nerve is damaged:

  • Loss of general (touch, pain, and temperature) sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Loss of taste sensation in that same region, since the lingual nerve carries taste fibers from the chorda tympani (branch of the facial nerve).
  • Possible reduction in saliva secretion, because the chorda tympani carries parasympathetic fibers that stimulate the submandibular and sublingual glands.

Course:

  • The lingual nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) in the infratemporal fossa.
  • It courses downward and forward, lying initially medial to the lateral pterygoid muscle and deep to the ramus of the mandible.
  • As it enters the floor of the mouth, it runs superficial to the hyoglossus muscle and deep to (and looping under) the submandibular duct, before ascending to supply the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • This intricate relationship places it at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Nerve to mylohyoid (Option A): A branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (V3) that innervates the mylohyoid and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle. Injury affects floor-of-mouth muscle function, but does not impact tongue sensation, taste, or salivation.

Inferior alveolar nerve (Option B): Traverses the mandibular canal to supply sensory branches to the lower teeth, the chin, and lower lip. Not anatomically related to the submandibular gland, so its injury would not explain deficits in tongue sensation or taste.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option D): Provides motor innervation to all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). Damage causes deviation of the tongue toward the affected side and motor impairment, but would not produce sensory or taste loss.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Lingual Nerve - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7), arising from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, supplies the flexor muscles of the arm and gives sensory supply to the lateral aspect of the forearm through its terminal branch, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

Key functions affected in this case:

  • Elbow flexion → Impaired due to paralysis of biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis.
  • Forearm supination → Weakened because the biceps brachii is affected (though not completely lost, as the supinator is still functional).
  • Sensory loss → Seen over the lateral forearm due to involvement of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Median nerve (Option A): Supplies most forearm flexors and thenar muscles. Sensory loss occurs over the lateral palm and first three fingers, not the lateral forearm. It does not control major elbow flexors or supination.

Radial nerve (Option B): Innervates the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Injury causes wrist drop and sensory loss over the posterior arm/forearm and dorsum of the hand-not the lateral forearm.

Ulnar nerve (Option D): Supplies intrinsic hand muscles and some forearm flexors. Sensory loss occurs over the medial hand and little finger, not the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A patient presenting with sciatica exhibits tenderness in the hamstring muscles. Which of the following nerves innervates a hybrid muscle that remains unaffected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is the Obturator nerve, as it supplies the adductor part of the hybrid muscles and remains unaffected in this condition.

  • Sciaticainvolves the sciatic nerve (L4-S3), which supplies the hamstrings (except for the short head of biceps femoris).
  • The adductor magnusis a hybrid muscle with dual innervation:
    • Adductor part→Obturator nerve (L2-L4)
    • Hamstring part→Tibial nerve (L4-S3)
  • Since the tibial nerveis affected in sciatica, the hamstring part of the adductor magnus is involved, but the adductor part (supplied by the obturator nerve) is spared.

Explanation for other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Incorrect because it supplies the rectus femoris, which is not relevant to sciatica.

Common peroneal nerve (Option B): Incorrect because it supplies the short head of biceps femoris, which can be affected in sciatica.

Tibial nerve (Option D) Incorrect because it is part of the sciatic nerve, meaning it is affected in this patient.

choices.text: A- Superior vena cava, B- Ascending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta
A- Ascending aorta, B- Descending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Superior vena cava
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior vena cava, C- Descending aorta, D- Pulmonary trunk,
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior Vena Cava, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta

questions.text: Identify the labelling correctly:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A - Superior Vena Cava: The superior vena cava is usually located on the right side of the image, returning deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart.

B - Ascending Aorta: The ascending aorta originates from the left ventricle and is positioned just slightly to the left of the superior vena cava.

C - Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is located just beneath the ascending aorta and carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.

D - Descending Aorta: The descending aorta is located posteriorly, descending downward after arching around the left side of the heart.

Great vessels in the thorax:

questions.text: A lesion in the Brodmann area 22 will cause:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodmann area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's area, located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left). A lesion in this area causes Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia, characterised by impaired comprehension and fluent but meaningless speech (word salad).

Explanation for other options:

Expressive aphasia (Option A): Expressive aphasia (Broca's aphasia) results from a lesion in Brodmann area 44 & 45 (Broca's area), causing non-fluent speech with intact comprehension.

Poor repetition of language (Option C): This is characteristic of conduction aphasia, which occurs due to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, disrupting communication between Wernicke's and Broca's areas.

Poor naming (Option D): While naming impairment can occur, it is not specific to Wernicke's aphasia; anomic aphasia primarily affects naming ability.

questions.text: Injury to which cranial nerve causes an absent gag reflex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Damage to either CN IX or CN X can lead to an absent gag reflex, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) and an increased risk of aspiration.

The gag reflex (pharyngeal reflex) involves both the afferent and efferent limbs controlled by cranial nerves:

Cranial Nerves and Reflexes:

Cranial nerves (CN) play a crucial role in reflexes by acting as afferent (sensory) or efferent (motor) pathways. Below is a summary of important cranial nerve-mediated reflexes:

Explanation for other options:

Cranial nerves X and VII (Option B): CN VII (Facial nerve) is involved in facial expression, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves VII and V (Option C): CN V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication, not the gag reflex.

Cranial nerves V and IX (Option D): CN V is not involved in the motor response of the gag reflex.

questions.text: Which artery lies in front of the Achilles tendon and behind the medial malleolus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior tibial artery passes behind the medial malleolus and runs in front of the Achilles tendon, within the tarsal tunnel. It provides blood supply to the posterior compartment of the leg and the plantar surface of the foot.

Explanation for other options:

Peroneal artery (Option B): It runs along the lateral compartment of the leg and does not pass behind the medial malleolus.

Anterior tibial artery (Option C): It passes anteriorly through the interosseous membrane and does not course behind the medial malleolus.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option D): It is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery and is located on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: Damage at which of the marked locations in the image would most likely result in an inability to dorsiflex the foot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The injury to the common fibular nerve causes failure of dorsiflexion; thus, the marked structure 3, i.e. neck of the fibula, is the right answer.

questions.text: A student experiences jaw locking during a yawn. Spasm of which muscle, attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint, is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

  • It plays a key role in the movement of the TMJ, particularly in opening the mouth and moving the jaw forward (protraction).

Lateral pterygoid:

  1. Attachment: The superior head of the lateral pterygoid inserts into the articular disc and the joint capsule, while the inferior head attaches to the neck of the mandible.
  2. Function: It helps in:
    • Depressing the mandible (opening the mouth).
    • Protrusion and lateral movements of the jaw.
  3. Spasmodic contraction: During excessive yawning, prolonged contraction of the lateral pterygoid can pull the articular disc and the mandible forward, potentially leading to jaw locking due to dislocation of the TMJ.

Explanation for other options:

Temporalis (Option B): This muscle primarily elevates and retracts the mandible; it has no attachment to the articular disc.

Medial pterygoid (Option C): Assists in elevation and side-to-side movements of the mandible but is not connected to the articular disc.

Masseter (Option D): A strong elevator of the mandible; also has no attachment to the articular disc.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Mastication Muscles - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient reports pain and swelling just below the left ear. Inflammation or involvement of which of the following anatomical structures is the most probable cause of the discomfort?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The greater auricular nerve, originating from the cervical plexus, innervates the skin around the ear, angle of the mandible, and parotid region.

  • It runs superficially along the neck and over the sternocleidomastoid muscle, making it prone to injury or irritation, leading to pain and swelling.
  • Pain and swelling under the left ear lobule could indicate involvement of this nerve, possibly due to inflammation or compression.

The External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus

questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The optic chiasma is positioned just above the anterior communicating artery (AComA) in the suprasellar cistern.

  • AComA aneurysms are the most common intracranial aneurysms.
  • These aneurysms can compress the optic chiasma, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes).
  • Clinical presentation may include vision loss, headache, and if ruptured, subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Anterior choroidal artery (Option B):

  • Branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • Supplies the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of internal capsule.
  • Aneurysms are rare and usually cause contralateral motor deficits, not compression of the optic chiasma.

Middle cerebral artery (Option C):

  • Does not run close to the optic chiasma.
  • MCA aneurysms typically affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (Option D):

  • Courses superior to the optic chiasma.
  • ACA aneurysms generally do not compress the chiasma directly.
  • ACA infarcts are classically associated with contralateral leg weakness due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

Reference: Anterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm Related to Visual Symptoms - PMC

questions.text: What structure is marked "X" in the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked "X" is the testicular vein, which courses along the posterior abdominal wall toward the deep inguinal ring.

  • The testicular vein is part of the spermatic cord and drains blood from the testis via the pampiniform plexus.
  • It ascends in the retroperitoneum, with the right testicular vein draining into the IVC, and the left testicular vein draining into the left renal vein.
  • In surgical anatomy, this structure is identified near the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels and anterior to the psoas major.
  • It is especially important in inguinal hernia repair, orchidectomy, and varicocele surgery.

Basic Surgical Anatomy of the Testis:

Location and Structure

Paired oval-shaped organs in the scrotum.

Suspended by the spermatic cord (contains blood vessels, nerves, vas deferens).

Layers:

  • Tunica Vaginalis:Double-layered serous membrane from the peritoneum.
  • Tunica Albuginea: Dense, fibrous capsule beneath the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on the clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The constellation of symptoms-including facial pain triggered by jaw movement and autonomic signs like lacrimation-points to involvement of the ophthalmic division (V₁) of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the upper face, eye region, and conveys ocular sensory signals

Trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve): Has three divisions


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

1 (Option A): (Most likely corresponds to V₂ or V₃)-These divisions supply the mid- and lower face or motor areas such as jaw muscles. They do not normally trigger lacrimation or photophobia, nor do they involve pain in the upper face or ocular region.

2 (Option B): (Likely V₂)-This division innervates the middle third of the face-cheeks, upper lip, upper teeth-but doesn't supply the forehead, eye region, or induce lacrimation or light sensitivity.

4 (Option D): (Likely V₃)-The mandibular branch affects lower facial sensation and mastication muscles. While clenching may trigger pain via V₃, the additional signs of headache, photophobia, or autonomic lacrimation point toward V₁ involvement.
